Ill
CIEAVAGE
Trace the first cleavages and note their relation to the axes
and symmetry of the egg. The first cleavage furrow lies in the plane
separating the right and left halves of the future embryo. See
figures by Watase.
thus
Note that the segmentation is meroblastic and also bilateral
differing from the typical molluscan eggs which are holoblastic.
Draw stages up to 8 or le cells. 
lt may`be of advantage to cover a depression slide with a
thin film of vaseline, or paraffine so that the eggs can be made to
stand up endwise for better observation. The same result may be
accomplished by crowding a larger number of cleaving eggs together
in a depression slide so that some of them stand on end.
the microscope in a horizontal position and jar the slide until some
eggs fall into a favorable position for observation.

This schedule was taken by Dr. B, Grave from observations on a mass

l. Study eggs which have been segmenting for longer periods,
several hours to two days. Note the extension of the blastoderm
about the yolk and its relation to the axes of the egg. Periblast
muelei and blastocones may be observed as well as a beautiful blas~
toderm an which cell outlines are visible. Draw.
2. Compare with the figures of Watase, Brooks and Naef. Does
the blastoderm finally completely enclose the yolk? See embryos
tnree or four days old.
